Some animal studies showed ADONA predominantly eliminated via urine with a half-life on the order of days. There is no official classification of ADONA as to carcinogenicity, but chronic studies are likely ongoing or not publicly available. Overall, while ADONA may have a somewhat lower toxicity profile than PFOA, it still can cause liver and developmental effects at elevated exposures, and its persistence raises concern. Any detection of ADONA in blood, for instance, would reflect recent environmental exposure and would be approached with similar caution to other emerging PFAS (monitoring health markers like liver enzymes, cholesterol, etc., would be prudent until more is known).

ADONA came under regulatory attention as part of PFAS reduction programs in the EU. It was introduced as a “safer” alternative to PFOA around 2010; however, European authorities have since scrutinized it. ADONA is included in the EU REACH regulation’s list of substances that companies had to register and provide data for. Germany’s Federal Institute for Risk Assessment (BfR) evaluated ADONA in 2017 when setting new safety limits for PFAS in drinking water, and ADONA is now often monitored in water near PFAS production. As of 2020, ADONA and its salts were added to the EU’s persistent organic pollutant regulation, effectively banning its use except in closed-loop industrial processes. Furthermore, ADONA is covered by the EU-wide restriction on PFOA which also encompasses related substances (though ADONA was specifically a proposed derogation at first, it was later voluntarily phased out by industry in Europe). Monitoring: Regulatory agencies in places like Germany and the Netherlands have required Chemours/Arkema to monitor and reduce ADONA emissions drastically. Environmental surveys in impacted regions include ADONA in their PFAS panels, and it has been detected in water and human serum of residents near those plants. In the US, ADONA might be captured under broad state PFAS regulations, but it’s not specifically regulated federally; however, UCMR5 (2023-2025) includes some ethers like HFPO-DA, not ADONA. Internationally, discussions are ongoing to possibly include ADONA (as part of the GenX class) in global treaties. For now, its production is limited to essentially one European site and perhaps one in China, under strict waste treatment requirements. In summary, ADONA’s regulatory status: it’s controlled as an emerging PFAS pollutant, with proactive measures in the EU to restrict emissions. Ongoing monitoring ensures ADONA levels in water supplies remain extremely low (for instance, local advisories in areas of contamination set limits in the ppt range). The move toward group regulation of PFAS means ADONA will likely fall under any broad PFAS restrictions in the future, effectively curtailing its use further.

Perfluorobutanoic acid (PFBA) is a perfluoroalkyl carboxylic acid with a four-carbon fully fluorinated chain (C3F7COOH):contentReference[oaicite:422]{index=422}. It is considered a "short-chain" PFAS. PFBA itself was not widely used as a commercial end-product; rather, it has been mainly an intermediate or degradation product. In industrial contexts, PFBA has been used in specialty applications such as an acid catalyst for certain chemical reactions or in pharmaceuticals, and as a building block in making some perfluorinated compounds:contentReference[oaicite:423]{index=423}. It may also have been used historically in small quantities as a solvent or reagent (for example, heptafluorobutyric acid – another name for PFBA – was used in analytical chemistry as an "Edman reagent" in protein sequencing). However, PFBA's significance arises primarily from its presence as an impurity or breakdown product of larger fluorochemicals. For instance, PFBA can be produced when some fluorotelomer compounds (used in stain-resistant textiles or paper coatings) break down over time:contentReference[oaicite:424]{index=424}. Additionally, 3M's phase-out documentations indicate PFBA can be a manufacturing by-product of older Scotchgard formulations. In consumer terms, PFBA is not intentionally present in products, but low levels have been detected in some food packaging or textiles due to its role in polymerization processes. In summary, PFBA’s direct uses are limited and technical, but it's a common environmental PFAS due to indirect formation through degradation of longer-chain PFAS and historical manufacturing processes.
PFBA is one of the more frequently detected PFAS in the environment and humans, often via pathways tied to water and food:
bullets: Drinking Water: PFBA is highly water-soluble and has been found in some contaminated water supplies (for example, in areas of Minnesota where PFAS were manufactured, PFBA was found in groundwater plume):contentReference[oaicite:428]{index=428}. It does not adsorb well to standard activated carbon filters compared to longer PFAS, meaning it can persist through some water treatment. Thus, ingestion of PFBA through drinking water can be a significant pathway in contaminated regions.

Food Consumption: Short-chain PFAS like PFBA can accumulate in certain produce. Studies have shown that garden vegetables grown in PFAS-contaminated soil or irrigated with contaminated water can uptake PFBA into edible portions (though it tends to accumulate less than longer chains). Additionally, because PFBA has been used in some food packaging (as part of coatings), there is potential for minute migration into food, though levels are usually very low.

Inhalation: PFBA is not particularly volatile (it’s an acid that will mostly stay in water), so inhalation exposure is less common. One scenario for inhalation could be aerosolized water (like showering or humidifiers using contaminated water) – however, the contribution from such would be minor relative to ingestion.

Occupational: Workers at facilities that historically produced or used PFBA or related chemicals might have had inhalation or dermal exposure. Given PFBA’s corrosive nature as an acid, direct handling could cause skin irritation and facilitate absorption. Modern exposure could occur at environmental labs or facilities treating PFAS waste, but in general PFBA occupational exposure is less of an issue compared to legacy PFAS like PFOA.

summary_sections.content: PFBA, as a short-chain PFAS, is less bioaccumulative in humans than long-chain PFAS (studies suggest it has a half-life on the order of days in humans). Nonetheless, toxicological studies indicate that PFBA can cause some of the hallmark PFAS effects at sufficiently high doses. Animal studies (e.g., in rats) have shown that PFBA exposure leads to liver enlargement and changes in liver enzymes, similar to other PFAS, though it generally requires higher doses than PFOA to elicit these changes. PFBA has also been found to affect thyroid hormone levels in animal tests and may mildly affect immune function. One distinctive finding: PFBA accumulates in the thyroid and liver of rodents to a higher extent relative to blood, raising concerns about thyroid disruption:contentReference[oaicite:430]{index=430}. There is limited data on PFBA’s carcinogenic potential; it has not been classified as a human carcinogen, and short-chain PFAS are generally considered less potent in this regard, but comprehensive cancer bioassays for PFBA are not well-documented publicly. Some research has pointed out that PFBA can exhibit estrogenic-like activity in vitro (binding to estrogen receptors):contentReference[oaicite:431]{index=431}, although the relevance of this at environmental exposures is unclear. Human epidemiology specifically for PFBA is scarce, but because PFBA is often present in serum (from water exposure), some studies have looked at combined PFAS exposure health effects. Overall, PFBA is considered to have lower toxicity on a per-weight basis than PFOA/PFOS, but still could contribute to cumulative PFAS health impacts such as cholesterol changes, liver effects, and possibly hormone modulation:contentReference[oaicite:432]{index=432}. Detection of PFBA in human blood is primarily an indicator of environmental exposure (likely water) and in itself does not pinpoint a known disease outcome; however, regulatory agencies remain cautious given PFBA’s ability to cause biological changes in lab tests (for instance, Minnesota Department of Health derived health guidelines for PFBA in water to guard against potential liver and thyroid effects in sensitive populations).

PFBA has caught the attention of regulators primarily at the state and international levels. In Minnesota (where 3M’s manufacturing resulted in PFBA contamination), the Department of Health set a health-based guidance value for PFBA in drinking water (parts per billion range) to ensure safety:contentReference[oaicite:435]{index=435}. Similarly, other local authorities in contaminated regions have included PFBA when testing water and issuing advisories. At the federal level in the US, PFBA is not individually regulated under the Safe Drinking Water Act; however, the EPA’s recent PFAS strategic roadmap indicates an intention to consider regulating additional PFAS beyond PFOA/PFOS as a class or subgroup. PFBA is being monitored under EPA’s UCMR5 (2023-2025) - in fact, PFBA is on the list of PFAS that large water systems will test for nationwide. Internationally, PFBA and its salts have been mentioned in the context of the Stockholm Convention’s deliberations (as part of the "C4–C7 PFCA" group for potential restrictions). The EU has already included PFBA (and other C4–C7 PFCAs) in its restrictions: as of July 2020, EU REACH regulations ban the manufacture or import of PFBA (and related chain lengths up to C13) in products above certain low concentrations:contentReference[oaicite:436]{index=436}. Therefore, PFBA is effectively regulated in the EU similarly to PFOA. Monitoring efforts: PFBA is commonly measured in groundwater and surface water as part of PFAS panels. Its presence in some agricultural areas (via irrigation) has prompted research on crop uptake. Regulatory focus is also on cleaning up legacy PFBA contamination; for instance, 3M has had to fund remediation of PFBA in Minnesota’s groundwater. In summary, while PFBA doesn’t have a national MCL in the US yet, it’s under close watch and included in broad regulatory measures in progressive jurisdictions. The trend is toward grouping PFBA with other PFAS for comprehensive regulatory action (like the proposed EU PFAS ban). Meanwhile, health advisory levels are in place in some regions to manage local risks from PFBA in water.

Perfluorodecanoic acid (PFDA) is a perfluorinated carboxylic acid with a ten-carbon fully fluorinated chain (C10HF19O2):contentReference[oaicite:445]{index=445}. PFDA is one of the higher homologues in the PFCAs series (extending beyond the widely known PFOA which is C8). There were no significant direct consumer applications of PFDA; rather, it has occurred as an impurity in or byproduct of the manufacturing of other PFAS and as a specialized industrial chemical. In the past, small amounts of PFDA may have been used in niche applications like surface treatments or as a component in certain fluoroelastomer curatives. It has also been used in some research contexts to study perfluorinated surfactants. Notably, PFDA can be generated unintentionally during electrochemical fluorination (the process 3M used to make PFOS and related compounds), meaning it was present in trace amounts in older Scotchgard formulations:contentReference[oaicite:446]{index=446}. Additionally, PFDA is known to form from the environmental breakdown or metabolism of some fluorotelomer compounds or side-chain fluoropolymers used in stain repellents:contentReference[oaicite:447]{index=447}. In effect, PFDA is more commonly encountered as a pollutant from PFAS production or degradation than as a deliberately used substance. With the phase-out of long-chain PFAS, PFDA is no longer manufactured intentionally (and any limited past uses have been largely discontinued). Therefore, its "use" context is largely historical and indirect—associated with PFAS manufacturing processes and present in older PFAS-containing products as a minor constituent:contentReference[oaicite:448]{index=448}.
People may be exposed to PFDA primarily through environmental and dietary routes, since it persists and bioaccumulates in food webs:
bullets: Dietary Ingestion: Bioaccumulation of PFDA in fish and marine mammals is significant because PFDA is highly hydrophobic. Consumption of contaminated fish (for example, from PFAS-impacted waters or near fluorochemical plant sites) can lead to PFDA intake. Studies in the Great Lakes and other regions have detected PFDA in fish tissue, so humans who eat those fish may ingest PFDA:contentReference[oaicite:452]{index=452}. It has also been found in some game and farm animals near contaminated sites via feed or water, potentially affecting food products (meat, milk, eggs) at low levels.

Drinking Water: PFDA has been found in some groundwater and surface water, but it tends to adsorb strongly to soils and sediments, so it’s less frequently a dominant PFAS in water relative to shorter chains. Nonetheless, near known contamination sources (like a PFAS production facility), PFDA can appear in well water. Ingesting such water without treatment can expose individuals, albeit PFDA concentrations are usually much lower than those of shorter PFAS due to its tendency to bind to soil.

House Dust and Indoor Air: PFDA could be present in indoor environments as part of the PFAS that migrate out of stain-resistant coatings on textiles or carpets over time, or from breakdown of precursor compounds (like some fluorotelomer-based treatments yield PFDA). Inhalation or ingestion of household dust might be a minor pathway for PFDA exposure, particularly for toddlers who have high dust ingestion rates. However, levels of PFDA in house dust are typically low compared to other PFAS (studies show it’s detectable but at lesser concentrations than, say, PFOS in dust).

Occupational Exposure: Workers in PFAS manufacturing (historic, as PFDA is not currently produced widely) could have been exposed via inhalation of aerosolized PFDA or dermal contact. Also, those involved in chrome plating with fume suppressants or other industries using PFAS may have incidental PFDA exposure. Currently, direct occupational exposure would mainly occur in industries handling legacy PFAS wastes or recycling electronics with PFAS – scenarios which are limited. In the past, however, chemical plant workers would have had higher PFDA exposure when it was present as a byproduct.

summary_sections.content: PFDA is a long-chain PFCA and exhibits toxicity profiles similar to PFOA, sometimes even more potent in certain aspects. It is highly persistent in the body; animal studies show PFDA has a long half-life (in rats, estimated half-life is longer than PFOA’s) and tends to accumulate in the liver and blood. Toxicologically, PFDA is a strong peroxisome proliferator in rodent livers, meaning it causes significant liver enlargement, increased fatty acid metabolism, and changes in liver enzymes:contentReference[oaicite:454]{index=454}. It has been shown to disrupt lipid regulation and cause reductions in serum cholesterol in rodents (a common PFAS effect):contentReference[oaicite:455]{index=455}. PFDA is considered one of the more immunotoxic PFAS; studies noted suppressed antibody responses in mice at relatively low serum concentrations. In vitro, PFDA can interfere with cell communication and mitochondrial function. There is also evidence that PFDA, like other long-chain PFAS, can act as an endocrine disruptor (for instance, affecting thyroid hormones and possibly estrogen receptor signaling). Regarding carcinogenicity, no dedicated long-term bioassay for PFDA is publicly available, but given its similarity to PFOA (which is likely carcinogenic to humans per EPA), it’s plausible PFDA poses a cancer risk as well. It’s notable that PFDA has been observed to cause more pronounced developmental toxicity than shorter PFAS in animal studies – including reduced fetal weight and delayed bone development at certain doses. In humans, PFDA is often detected in serum (though at much lower levels than PFOS or PFOA) and has been associated in some cross-sectional studies with outcomes like altered vaccine antibody levels and elevated liver enzymes, consistent with known PFAS effects. Overall, PFDA is considered a highly bioactive PFAS despite less human data, and health agencies treat it as a chemical of concern in the PFAS class:contentReference[oaicite:456]{index=456}. Its presence in blood signals cumulative exposure to a substance known to affect liver, immune, and developmental parameters in experimental systems.

PFDA is one of the long-chain PFAS that regulators are targeting for elimination. In the European Union, PFDA and its salts were included in the 2020 restriction of C9-C14 PFCAs, which means manufacture or use of PFDA above 25 ppb in products is banned (with very limited exemptions):contentReference[oaicite:459]{index=459}. PFDA is also listed in Annex B of the Stockholm Convention as part of “PFOA, its salts and related compounds” (PFDA qualifies as a related compound due to chain length), thus subject to global phase-out measures starting 2020. In the United States, there’s no PFDA-specific federal standard yet, but PFDA is subject to state-level criteria in some cases. For example, the State of Michigan set groundwater cleanup criteria for “total long-chain PFCAs” including PFDA; and Alaska’s guidance levels for drinking water include PFDA in the sum of PFAS limits. The EPA’s ongoing PFAS monitoring (UCMR5) will capture PFDA occurrences in drinking water from 2023 onward. Monitoring: PFDA is regularly included in biomonitoring studies (like CDC’s NHANES) and although detection frequencies in the general U.S. population are lower than for PFOS/PFOA, it is measured in exposed subpopulations. Many fish and wildlife monitoring programs (Great Lakes fish, Arctic biota) measure PFDA due to its bioaccumulation; for instance, PFDA is monitored as part of Canada’s chemical management plan in wildlife. Remediation efforts at contaminated sites (like those near PFAS production plants) set performance goals that encompass PFDA – e.g., a site might have to reduce total PFAS including PFDA to below certain ppt levels in groundwater. Because PFDA isn’t often found alone, regulatory approaches frequently handle it within a class: for example, some proposed drinking water standards consider a combined limit for multiple PFAS including PFDA. In summary, PFDA is effectively being regulated through broad PFAS restrictions internationally, and ongoing monitoring ensures its levels in environment and biota are tracked and, ideally, decreasing as manufacturing sources have ceased.

Perfluoroheptanoic acid (PFHpA) is a seven-carbon perfluorinated carboxylic acid (C6F13COOH). It is one homologue shorter than PFOA. PFHpA was not widely manufactured on its own; instead it appears as a byproduct or impurity in the production of other fluorochemicals and as a degradation product of some precursor compounds:contentReference[oaicite:465]{index=465}. For instance, during electrochemical fluorination (historically used by 3M), PFHpA could form in small quantities alongside PFOS and PFOA. PFHpA can also originate from the breakdown of 8:2 fluorotelomer compounds (which may lose one CF2 unit to form the C7 acid). There have been niche uses of PFHpA’s ammonium salt in certain semiconductor manufacturing processes or as a reference chemical in research, but these are not consumer-level uses. Essentially, PFHpA's presence in commerce is as part of "long-chain" PFAS technical mixtures or as an unintended contaminant. Like other long-chain PFCAs, its use has been phased out where possible. It is worth noting that PFHpA is often found in low concentrations in older formulations of stain-repellent coatings (as an impurity) and in the environment near PFAS production facilities. In summary, PFHpA itself isn’t known for any specific product use; its significance is tied to being one of the suite of perfluorocarboxylates arising from PFAS manufacturing and degradation:contentReference[oaicite:466]{index=466}.
Human exposure to PFHpA typically occurs alongside other PFAS, through common pathways like:
bullets: Drinking Water: PFHpA has been detected in water supplies impacted by PFAS contamination (for instance, near airports or fluorochemical plants). People consuming contaminated water can ingest PFHpA. It's usually present at lower levels than PFHxA or PFOA, but still contributes to total PFAS intake. Water is a primary pathway especially for communities near known PFAS sites where PFHpA shows up as part of the PFAS fingerprint.

Food: PFHpA can accumulate modestly in the food chain. Fish from contaminated water bodies may contain PFHpA in their tissue (though it accumulates less than longer chains). Dairy or produce can also have traces if grown or raised in areas with PFAS in soil/water. Overall diet contributions of PFHpA in the general population are probably very low, but for subsistence fishers or farmers in contaminated regions, it could be more significant.

Indoor Dust: Studies of indoor dust have found PFHpA along with other PFAS, presumably from degradation of stain-resistant treatments in carpets or textiles. Ingestion of or hand-to-mouth contact with house dust could thus expose individuals, particularly toddlers, to small quantities of PFHpA. Inhalation of dust is a minor contributor but possible.

Occupational: Workers at facilities that produced or used PFAS in the past may have encountered PFHpA in the processing streams (e.g., in quality control labs or waste handling). Today, workers at remediation sites or in firefighting training areas (due to AFFFs containing PFAS) might incidentally contact PFHpA. However, direct occupational exposure specifically to PFHpA is not common.

summary_sections.content: PFHpA falls into the category of long-chain perfluorocarboxylic acids, so its toxicological profile is expected to resemble those of PFOA and PFNA, albeit with somewhat intermediate potency. There is limited published data focusing solely on PFHpA, but it is known to be persistent in the body (though slightly less so than PFOA; for example, half-life in lab animals is shorter for C7 vs C8). Toxicologically, PFHpA has been observed to cause liver hypertrophy and peroxisome proliferation in rodents, indicating liver stress and enzyme induction—this is consistent with other PFCAs. It likely influences lipid metabolism (PFHpA exposure in animals could lower blood cholesterol and triglycerides, as seen with PFOA). Immune system effects are probable as well, given PFHpA’s structural similarity to PFNA (which has documented immunotoxicity). No dedicated carcinogenicity studies on PFHpA have been publicized, but by analogy, it could have tumor-promoting activity in rodent liver like PFOA, albeit data is insufficient for human cancer risk determination. The EPA and other agencies often consider health effects of PFHpA in conjunction with PFOA, PFNA, etc., because they act on similar biological pathways. Human data: PFHpA is measured in human serum in some exposed populations (though usually at much lower concentrations than PFOA or PFOS). Some epidemiological analyses have noted associations between combined PFHpA (plus other PFAS) levels and outcomes like thyroid hormone fluctuations or renal function markers, but it's hard to attribute specifically to PFHpA. Overall, PFHpA is presumed to contribute to the general health concerns of long-chain PFAS—such as potential developmental, liver, and immune effects—even though it's less studied individually. Thus, if PFHpA is present in blood, it is treated with similar caution as PFOA or PFNA with respect to the need to minimize exposure and monitor related health indicators.

PFHpA is regulated collectively with other long-chain PFAS in various jurisdictions. In the EU, the 2020 restriction on C9-C14 perfluorocarboxylic acids also encompassed PFHpA indirectly, because PFHpA (C7) is not within C9-C14 but it is often present as a minor impurity with those acids; moreover, the EU already had earlier restrictions on C6 and longer in certain uses. Some European countries explicitly include PFHpA in their PFAS drinking water guidelines (for instance, as part of a sum of PFAS limit). In the US, PFHpA is one of the PFAS that the EPA is requiring water utilities to monitor under UCMR5 (unregulated contaminant monitoring rule) during 2023-2025. Several states have rolled PFHpA into their regulatory framework by setting “total PFAS” limits in drinking water (e.g., the Massachusetts 20 ppt limit for 6 PFAS includes PFHpA). Additionally, PFHpA is often part of site cleanup criteria; for example, Michigan’s groundwater cleanup standard covers PFHpA with a specific value of 51 ppt (enforced as part of a 7-PFAS criteria list). Monitoring: Environmental agencies and researchers monitor PFHpA in water, soil, and biota as part of comprehensive PFAS scans. PFHpA frequently appears in environmental datasets as a low-percentage component of PFAS contamination profiles. As regulatory focus broadens to all PFAS, PFHpA is likely to be encompassed by any class-based regulation. For instance, Canada’s guidance on PFAS in drinking water (proposed in 2023) included PFHpA in the suite of PFAS covered by a 30 ppt limit. Also, the upcoming EU PFAS ban proposal would restrict production/use of any PFAS with few exceptions, meaning PFHpA would be phased out in remaining applications. In summary, while PFHpA might not have stand-alone regulations, it is effectively regulated through group measures (like sum of PFAS limits) and is a required analyte in new monitoring efforts, ensuring that its presence is controlled and that remediation efforts address it alongside other PFAS.

Perfluorohexanoic acid (PFHxA) is a six-carbon perfluorinated carboxylic acid (C5F11COOH). It is a short-chain PFAS that is often regarded as a breakdown product or impurity rather than a deliberately used chemical in most cases. PFHxA emerges primarily from the degradation of C6 fluorotelomer compounds, which have been used in various consumer products (e.g., stain-resistant coatings, waterproofing treatments) after the phase-out of longer chains:contentReference[oaicite:469]{index=469}. In terms of industrial use, ammonium PFHxA may have limited application as a processing aid or intermediate in manufacturing some fluoropolymers or specialty chemicals. For example, some manufacturers switched to C6-based surfactants in chromium plating mist suppressants and in certain firefighting foams (where PFHxA can be a component or byproduct). PFHxA itself is not known to be used in finished consumer goods, but it can be present at low levels in items treated with C6 fluorotelomer-based formulations (like textile finishes or food packaging coatings). With the regulatory shift away from long-chain PFAS, C6 chemistry (which leads to PFHxA as an end-of-life product) became prominent; thus PFHxA is considered an “intended” end product of the newer PFAS formulations, albeit typically not isolated. In summary, PFHxA’s common presence is as an environmental metabolite of C6 fluorotelomers and an impurity in C6-based PFAS products, rather than a stand-alone commercial product sold for consumer use:contentReference[oaicite:470]{index=470}.
People can be exposed to PFHxA through pathways broadly similar to other perfluoroalkyl acids, especially via water and possibly treated consumer goods:
bullets: Drinking Water: PFHxA has been detected in drinking water sources impacted by PFAS pollution. As a shorter-chain acid, it’s relatively mobile in groundwater. Communities near facilities producing fluorotelomer products or areas where PFAS-containing foams were used (air force bases, firefighting training areas) often find PFHxA in water. Thus, ingestion of contaminated drinking water is a primary exposure route in those cases.

Food and Packaging: PFHxA can migrate in trace amounts from grease-resistant food packaging that use C6 fluorotelomer coatings. While industry data suggest migration is low, it is a possible minor source (like from a fast-food wrapper to food). Additionally, crops irrigated with reclaimed water containing PFHxA might uptake small amounts, and fish from contaminated water can contain PFHxA in their tissues. So dietary exposure via produce, fish, or possibly dairy (cows drinking PFAS-laden water) can occur, albeit at low levels.

House Dust and Treated Textiles: Residual PFHxA can be present in homes, either shed from stain-proofed carpets/upholstery or as the result of fluorotelomer substances on textiles breaking down. Inhalation or ingestion of house dust may therefore contribute to PFHxA exposure. Also, direct skin contact with PFAS-treated fabrics theoretically could transfer tiny amounts of PFHxA or precursors to the body (though dermal uptake of these acids is limited).

Occupational: Workers in plants making or using C6 fluorotelomer products may inhale air or contact liquids containing PFHxA (for instance, in quality control labs measuring breakdown products, or if there are emissions in production areas). Firefighters using modern PFAS-containing foams (which are now often C6-based) could be intermittently exposed to PFHxA as a component in those foams through skin or inhalation of mist. Generally, occupational exposures for PFHxA specifically are not prominently documented but would occur as part of exposure to the broader mix of PFAS in those settings.

summary_sections.content: PFHxA is considered less bioaccumulative and toxic than the long-chain PFOA/PFNA, but it is not without effects. Animal studies on PFHxA (and its salts) show that it is rapidly eliminated (half-life on the order of <1 day in rodents), and does not significantly accumulate in serum or liver with repeated dosing (compared to PFOA):contentReference[oaicite:472]{index=472}. Nonetheless, at high doses, PFHxA has caused some similar patterns of toxicity: e.g., slight liver weight increases and mild liver cell hypertrophy in rodents (indicative of peroxisome proliferation), though typically at doses much higher than those that affect the liver with PFOA. Reproductive and developmental studies in rats have generally found PFHxA to have no observable adverse effect at moderate doses, except at very high exposures where reduced fetal body weights were noted. Immunotoxicity data is sparse, but shorter PFAS like PFHxA have shown less suppression of immune responses in animal models than longer ones. Importantly, PFHxA has not shown significant binding to proteins like perfluorinated longer acids do, which might underlie its lower biological persistence. Chronic or cancer studies on PFHxA are not publicly well-documented; however, given its mode of action is likely similar (PPARα activation), any theoretical risk of tumor promotion in liver is probably lower due to rapid clearance. Epidemiologically, since PFHxA is usually at or below detection in human serum in the general population, human health associations specifically with PFHxA have not been established. Many regulatory agencies (like Australia’s enHealth) have concluded that the current evidence indicates low toxicity for PFHxA relative to other PFAS, but they still apply precautionary approaches due to unknowns. In summary, PFHxA appears to pose less risk to human health than longer-chain PFAS, but extremely high exposures might still cause liver enzyme changes or developmental effects in animals:contentReference[oaicite:473]{index=473}. Its detection in humans is primarily a marker of environmental exposure and not currently linked to specific health outcomes, but health advisories aim to keep PFHxA exposures minimal as part of overall PFAS reduction.

PFHxA is often addressed in the context of total PFAS regulations and advisories. As a short-chain, it was not covered by earlier PFOA/PFOS bans, but regulators are now broadening scope. The EU chemicals agency (ECHA) considered PFHxA and its salts in a 2019 restriction proposal distinct from the C9-C14 ban; in fact, in August 2023 the EU formally adopted a restriction on PFHxA, its salts and related substances (targeting manufacture and use of PFHxA above 25 ppb, with some time-limited exemptions, especially for high-performance plastics):contentReference[oaicite:475]{index=475}. This essentially will phase out any remaining uses of PFHxA in the EU. In the US, PFHxA is included in EPA's nationwide monitoring (UCMR5) and is part of the risk assessments being done by states: for example, California’s notification levels for drinking water include PFHxA at 0.0003 mg/L (300 ppt) as an advisory level. Several states like Massachusetts regulate PFHxA as part of their "sum of 6 PFAS" drinking water standard (20 ppt combined). Australia’s guidelines have set a relatively higher tolerance for PFHxA in drinking water (for example, 410 µg/L for adults) compared to PFOS/PFOA, reflecting its lower toxicity. Monitoring wise, many contaminated sites now test for PFHxA as one of the suite of PFAS analytes, since it's a marker of C6-based contamination. PFHxA frequently appears in groundwater near airports where modern AFFF is used, so it’s tracked in remedial investigations. On the consumer product side, some voluntary movements are underway to reduce all PFAS, including short chains, in items like food packaging—some jurisdictions (e.g., certain US states) have enacted bans on PFAS in food packaging, which would inherently eliminate PFHxA from that source. The anticipated EU PFAS umbrella restriction (currently in proposal) would group-ban virtually all PFAS including PFHxA except in essential uses. In summary, while PFHxA had been tolerated as a safer alternative, regulators are now actively restricting it, driven by persistence in the environment. Current standards treat PFHxA more leniently toxicity-wise, but the trend is toward eliminating releases of all PFAS, PFHxA included, and monitoring it diligently in water supplies to ensure it stays at very low levels.

Perfluorononanoic acid (PFNA) is a nine-carbon perfluorinated carboxylic acid (C8F17COOH) that belongs to the same class as PFOA but with one additional CF2 group. PFNA was never produced as high-volume as PFOS or PFOA; however, it had some specialized applications and appeared as a byproduct in PFAS manufacturing. PFNA (often in ammonium salt form) was used in limited quantities as a processing aid in the manufacture of certain fluoropolymers and fluoroelastomers, similar to PFOA's role:contentReference[oaicite:480]{index=480}. For example, it was reportedly used in the past by a Japanese manufacturer (Daikin) for some polymerization processes. Additionally, PFNA has been used as a component in some adhesives and anticorrosion coatings, though these uses are not well-publicized. More commonly, PFNA arose unintentionally: it is a minor impurity formed during electrochemical fluorination (the historic 3M process for PFOS) and was present at low levels in some legacy products like Aqueous Film Forming Foams (AFFFs) and industrial surfactant blends:contentReference[oaicite:481]{index=481}. With the shift away from long-chain PFAS, any limited use of PFNA has ceased. Today, PFNA is mainly encountered as an environmental contaminant and in biomonitoring, rather than an active ingredient in products. It’s noteworthy that PFNA is one of the PFAS that has consistently been detected in human blood at low levels, often arising from past exposures via food or water:contentReference[oaicite:482]{index=482}.
Exposure to PFNA can occur through several routes, largely overlapping with those of PFOA/PFOS:
bullets: Drinking Water: PFNA has been found in certain drinking water supplies, particularly near facilities that made or used PFAS. For instance, water near some PFAS production plants (in New Jersey or Minnesota, USA) contained notable PFNA levels:contentReference[oaicite:485]{index=485}. Consumption of contaminated water is a primary pathway. PFNA, being long-chain, strongly sorbs to activated carbon, so well-maintained filters can reduce it, but unfiltered water intake contributes to exposure.

Food: Like other long-chain PFAS, PFNA accumulates in the food chain. Fish from contaminated waters (e.g., in the Delaware River or Great Lakes where PFNA has been measured in sediment) can contain PFNA. Consuming those fish or wildlife (game animals near contaminated sites) can expose individuals. Additionally, PFNA has been detected in some food items in studies (milk, eggs, meat) albeit at very low concentrations; these likely originate from animals drinking contaminated water or feed.

Indoor Dust and Consumer Products: PFNA can be present in household dust, as it was a minor component of certain stain-resistant treatments historically. Ingestion of or inhalation of dust (especially by infants/toddlers on carpets) could contribute a small fraction of PFNA exposure. Certain older consumer products (like coated fabrics or AFFF-stained gear) might have trace PFNA. However, direct exposure from consumer products is generally minimal compared to water/food.

Occupational: Workers at PFAS manufacturing plants (especially historically, before PFNA was regulated) could have had significant exposure via inhalation of aerosols or dust containing PFNA and via skin contact. For example, PFNA was used by a chemical plant in New Jersey, and workers there showed elevated blood PFNA. Firefighters using older AFFFs might inhale PFNA-containing mist or have dermal contact during training and incidents, though the amount per event would be small. Cleanup crews at contaminated sites also face potential contact with PFNA in soil or water if not properly protected.

summary_sections.content: PFNA is considered one of the more toxic long-chain PFAS, with potency similar to or greater than PFOA in some respects. It is persistent in humans (estimated half-life ~4 years) and binds strongly to blood proteins. Animal studies show that PFNA, like other PFCAs, causes enlargement of the liver, developmental toxicity, immune suppression, and hormonal changes. Notably, a developmental study in mice found PFNA to cause offspring birth weight reduction and delays in development at lower doses than PFOA:contentReference[oaicite:487]{index=487}. PFNA also appeared to suppress antibody production in a rodent immune study, indicating immunotoxicity. Some data suggest PFNA may disrupt thyroid hormone homeostasis and cause slight changes in reproductive organs in animal tests. EPA's health advisory documentation (2022) treated PFNA similarly to PFOA, using a composite reference dose for PFOA/PFNA due to observed links with elevated cholesterol and serum liver enzymes in human populations:contentReference[oaicite:488]{index=488}:contentReference[oaicite:489]{index=489}. Epidemiological evidence associates PFNA exposure with increased serum cholesterol, and some studies have found associations with reduced birth weight in humans (mirroring animal findings). While no human cancer has been definitively tied to PFNA alone, its mechanistic similarity to PFOA (which has been linked to kidney and testicular cancers in highly exposed groups) raises concerns. IARC has not separately evaluated PFNA, but regulatory bodies like ATSDR have included it in their toxicological profile for PFAS as a chemical of concern. In summary, PFNA shares the adverse effect profile of PFOA/PFOS—affecting liver, metabolic, developmental, and immune systems—and likely has equal or greater potency on a per-weight basis in some endpoints:contentReference[oaicite:490]{index=490}. Therefore, detection of PFNA in blood is taken seriously as an indicator of meaningful PFAS exposure with potential health implications, especially for sensitive groups like pregnant women or infants.

PFNA has been targeted by regulators especially in regions with known contamination. For example, New Jersey was the first US state to set a formal Maximum Contaminant Level (MCL) for PFNA in drinking water, at 13 ppt (parts per trillion) as of 2018:contentReference[oaicite:493]{index=493}, due to high levels found near a Solvay facility. This strict standard forced water systems in NJ to install treatment if PFNA exceeded that level. Federally in the US, PFNA is included in EPA’s health advisory (2022) as part of the interim combined PFOA/PFOS guideline (EPA assumed similar risk and set combined interim levels in the low ppt). PFNA is also listed among the PFAS for monitoring under UCMR5. It's expected that PFNA could be encompassed in any future federal PFAS MCLs, potentially under a “hazard index” or grouped approach. Internationally, the Stockholm Convention’s 2019 global ban on PFOA includes its “related compounds” of chain lengths 7-14, which means PFNA falls under that elimination mandate (with only specific exemptions like certain medical devices until alternatives are found). In the EU, PFNA and its salts were added to the REACH SVHC (Substances of Very High Concern) list and are part of the 2020 restriction on C9-C14 PFCAs, making it illegal to manufacture or use PFNA above 25 ppb in products (with minor exemptions):contentReference[oaicite:494]{index=494}. Monitoring: PFNA is regularly measured in environmental and biological monitoring programs. CDC’s NHANES has tracked PFNA in the US population, noting a decline in serum PFNA since the early 2000s, though it’s still detectable in over 95% of people. Many states now require well testing for PFNA near contaminated sites. On the industrial side, companies have had to virtually eliminate PFNA from emissions: the Solvay agreement in NJ, for instance, demanded installation of PFNA treatment and community blood testing. Overall, PFNA is heavily regulated now – essentially being phased out globally and monitored to ensure legacy contamination is identified and addressed. Water utilities across several US states (like Michigan, Massachusetts, New York) have enforceable or guidance levels for PFNA (generally between 6 and 13 ppt). With the momentum of PFAS regulation, PFNA will remain a key chemical of concern until levels in the environment and population recede to very low levels, which is the public health goal.

Perfluoropentanoic acid (PFPeA) is a five-carbon perfluorinated carboxylic acid (C4F9COOH), classed as a short-chain PFAS. There were no major industrial or commercial products intentionally based on PFPeA; instead, PFPeA typically appears as a minor byproduct or degradant. It can be formed during the production or breakdown of other fluorochemicals, especially those with C6 chains (since losing one CF2 from PFHxA yields PFPeA). For instance, PFPeA can be present at low concentrations in some “C6” fluorotelomer-based firefighting foams or repellent formulations as an impurity:contentReference[oaicite:501]{index=501}. It might also be generated in the environment as intermediate when longer chain PFAS degrade (although shorter PFAS like PFPeA are pretty stable, they can come from precursors losing fragments). PFPeA has limited direct utility, but in some specialized chemical processes, salts of PFPeA (like ammonium PFPeA) might have been tested for polymerization aid roles or other niche uses, though any such uses were minor or experimental. With the focus on short-chain PFAS as alternatives, PFPeA’s presence is mostly incidental. In summary, PFPeA doesn’t have significant standalone uses; it is primarily encountered as part of the PFAS mixture released from manufacturing or in trace amounts in newer PFAS-containing products, rather than being intentionally added on its own.
The general public's exposure to PFPeA happens through similar channels as other PFAS, albeit PFPeA is often a small fraction of total PFAS burden:
bullets: Drinking Water: PFPeA has been detected in water downstream of PFAS sources (like in areas of fluorochemical manufacturing or heavy AFFF use). Because it's even more mobile than PFHxA, it can travel with groundwater plumes. Thus, ingestion of contaminated drinking water is a plausible pathway, as observed in some communities during PFAS well testing (PFPeA usually co-occurs with other PFAS at lower levels).

Food Consumption: PFPeA can accumulate to a limited extent in crops and aquatic life. Vegetables irrigated with PFAS-impacted water may take up some PFPeA, though short-chain PFAS uptake into edible parts is not very high. Fish from contaminated water have shown presence of PFPeA (like in certain rivers studied for PFAS, PFPeA is found in fish plasma or liver). Eating such fish or produce could contribute to PFPeA intake, albeit minor relative to other PFAS.

Indoor Environment: PFPeA has been identified in house dust and indoor air in low concentrations, likely emanating from treated consumer products or indoor PFAS sources. Inhalation or ingestion of dust could expose individuals to PFPeA. For example, houses with carpet or textiles treated with fluorotelomer-based repellents might have a small content of PFPeA in dust via breakdown of those coatings.

Occupational: Workers involved in remediation or firefighting may encounter PFPeA as part of PFAS mixtures. For example, firefighters using modern foams (which are mostly C6-based) could contact PFPeA residually present. Similarly, workers at municipal waste treatment plants might be exposed to low levels of PFPeA because it is not well removed by conventional wastewater processes and could be present in aerosols or biosolids. While occupational exposure specifically to PFPeA is rarely singled out, it’s encompassed in general PFAS exposure at certain jobs.

summary_sections.content: PFPeA is one of the shortest PFCAs studied. Due to its small size, it is eliminated relatively rapidly from the body (likely on the order of days) and does not accumulate in blood or organs to the same extent as long-chain PFAS. Toxicological data on PFPeA itself are limited, but we can infer from PFBA (C4) and PFHxA (C6) data that PFPeA likely has even lower toxicity. Short-chain PFAS generally show fewer of the adverse effects that long-chains do, often requiring much higher doses to see changes. It's expected that PFPeA, like PFBA, might cause transient mild liver weight increases or slight changes in metabolic enzymes at high doses, but robust toxic endpoints (like significant developmental toxicity, immune suppression, or cancer) have not been reported for these short chains in the sparse literature. A study on analogous short PFCAs found no significant developmental or reproductive harm at moderate dose levels. No regulatory agency has derived a specific reference dose or health advisory specifically for PFPeA, likely due to this low toxicity profile and lower occurrence data. Moreover, PFPeA's strong polarity and small size means it may not bind efficiently to proteins like albumin or receptors that longer PFAS do, possibly resulting in less biological activity. However, caution is still warranted, as extremely high exposures could cause the generic acidic irritant effects (e.g., high concentrations might lead to gastrointestinal irritation or enzyme induction in liver). In humans, PFPeA is rarely measured in serum (it's often below detection or lumped into total PFAS measurements) and thus epidemiological links are not established. Overall, PFPeA is considered to have comparatively minimal health impact relative to notorious PFAS like PFOA or PFOS, though comprehensive studies are lacking. Regulators often focus on PFPeA as part of total PFAS more out of persistence and mobility concerns than direct toxicity concerns.

PFPeA is not individually regulated by most authorities, but it falls under broader PFAS controls. For example, the EU's 2023 proposal to ban all PFAS would naturally include PFPeA, disallowing its production or marketing except in essential uses. Prior to that, PFPeA wasn't included in the C9-C14 PFCA restriction (because it's shorter than C9), but some national regulations capture it via total organic fluorine limits or as part of a 'short-chain PFAS' grouping. In the U.S., a few states incorporate PFPeA in their guidelines: for instance, Michigan’s cleanup criteria assess a suite of seven PFAS including PFPeA for groundwater at contaminated sites. EPA’s UCMR5 monitoring list did not specifically list PFPeA (it focuses on chain lengths 4 and 6 sulfonates and 6+ carboxylates like PFHxA and above), so national monitoring data for PFPeA may be limited. However, advanced labs often detect PFPeA in water testing when doing comprehensive PFAS scans, and regulatory agencies look at it to complete the mass balance of PFAS at contaminated sites. Because PFPeA is very mobile in the environment, its presence has been noted as a marker of how far PFAS plumes travel – for instance, New Hampshire regulators commented on detection of PFPeA at downgradient wells as an early indicator of contamination spread. There's no specific drinking water standard for PFPeA; it tends to be encompassed under 'total PFAS' limits. For example, states like Vermont have a combined 20 ppt MCL for five PFAS including PFPeA. Analytical reporting in environmental permits (like NPDES wastewater permits) sometimes require monitoring of PFPeA as part of a PFAS suite, ensuring industrial dischargers track even the short chains. As regulatory focus intensifies, it's likely that PFPeA will be regulated not by itself but through these class-based approaches (sum totals, etc.). In summary, PFPeA’s regulatory context is one of inclusion in broad PFAS restrictions and monitoring rather than targeted rulemaking; it's measured and controlled as part of achieving near-zero PFAS emissions in general.

Perfluorotetradecanoic acid (PFTeDA) is a fourteen-carbon perfluorinated carboxylic acid (C13F27COOH), making it one of the longest fully fluorinated carboxylates historically identified in PFAS chemistry:contentReference[oaicite:503]{index=503}. PFTeDA was not a commercial product in its own right; instead, it usually appeared as a byproduct or impurity in the manufacture of other PFAS, especially during electrochemical fluorination processes that produced mixtures of perfluorinated carboxylic acids up to C14. It is sometimes called "C14 PFCA". There were no known direct consumer or industrial applications for PFTeDA due to its very high molecular weight and extremely low solubility; it wasn't intentionally used like PFOA or PFOS. However, trace amounts of PFTeDA could be found in older aqueous film-forming foams (AFFFs) and in products like fluoropolymers as unintended residuals from using longer-chain telomers or ECF-based starting materials. With the phase-out of long-chain PFAS, any incidental production of PFTeDA has also ceased (manufacturers stopped making mixtures containing PFTeDA). Thus, PFTeDA’s presence in the environment now is essentially a relic of past production and usage of PFAS mixtures. In summary, PFTeDA had no separate "uses"; it is notable primarily as one of the long-chain PFAS species present in legacy formulations and as a component of contamination profiles at PFAS-impacted sites:contentReference[oaicite:504]{index=504}.
As a very long-chain PFAS, PFTeDA exposure is usually accompanied by exposure to other PFAS and via similar routes, though PFTeDA's own properties somewhat limit its mobility:
bullets: Food Chain Bioaccumulation: PFTeDA strongly adsorbs to organic matter and is bioaccumulative. Humans may be exposed by eating fish or wildlife from contaminated ecosystems where PFTeDA from historical PFAS releases has built up in the food web. For instance, top predator fish in some contaminated lakes/rivers have measurable PFTeDA, and consuming such fish can lead to ingestion of PFTeDA (in addition to other PFAS).

Drinking Water: Because of its large size and low solubility, PFTeDA is less commonly found in water compared to shorter PFAS. It tends to stick to soils and sediments. However, near direct sources (like a spill or disposal site of PFAS waste), PFTeDA can leach slowly. If groundwater near such a site is used for drinking without treatment, PFTeDA exposure could occur, albeit typically at much lower concentrations than shorter chain PFCAs:contentReference[oaicite:507]{index=507}. Most drinking water treatments (activated carbon, etc.) are effective at removing PFTeDA given its strong adsorptive behavior.

Consumer Products and Dust: PFTeDA is not volatile and was not in consumer products purposely. It might be present in trace amounts in older stain-resistant carpet or fabric treatments (since those had a distribution of chain lengths). Thus, household dust in homes with extensive historic use of such treatments could contain minimal PFTeDA. Ingestion of dust by infants or toddlers could then be a minuscule pathway. Overall, exposure from indoor environments is considered negligible for PFTeDA specifically.

Occupational: In past manufacturing environments, workers could have been exposed to PFTeDA by handling PFAS intermediates containing it or from emissions (e.g., inhaling fumes or dust during powder drying of fluoropolymers). Currently, direct occupational exposure to PFTeDA is rare, but people involved in remediation (like excavating soils at a PFAS dumpsite) could come into dermal or inhalation contact with soil-bound PFTeDA. Due to its low volatility, inhalation would primarily occur attached to particulate dust rather than vapor.

summary_sections.content: There is limited toxicological research specifically on PFTeDA. However, as an ultra-long-chain PFCA, it is expected to be even more bioaccumulative and potentially biologically active per unit than PFOA/PFNA. In lab animals, similar chain length PFCAs (like PFDoA, C12) caused significant weight loss, hepatic enlargement, and mortality at lower doses than shorter PFAS, indicating high potency. It's plausible that PFTeDA, if it enters the body, strongly binds to proteins and has a very long elimination half-life (potentially on the order of many years, extrapolating from known PFAS trends). No chronic or carcinogenicity studies have been published on PFTeDA itself, but structure–activity trends suggest that risk of liver damage, endocrine disruption, and possibly cancer could be present with enough exposure. Realistically, though, exposures are low and mainly co-occur with other PFAS, making it hard to isolate PFTeDA effects. It's worth noting that in wildlife, high-chain PFCAs like PFTeDA are often found in liver and blood of top predators, and these have been linked to health changes (e.g., immune or reproductive effects) in those animals. For humans, PFTeDA is detected in serum only occasionally (often below quantifiable levels in general population, but found in some highly exposed subgroups). The human health effect data is lacking; one can infer from associated PFAS that PFTeDA would contribute to elevated cholesterol, liver enzyme changes, and hormone level shifts if present in significant amounts. Regulatory agencies treat PFTeDA with a high concern due to its extreme persistence and potential for cumulative toxicity. Overall, while direct evidence is sparse, PFTeDA is assumed to be among the more hazardous PFAS on a per-mass basis, and controlling exposure to essentially zero is the prudent course from a health perspective.

PFTeDA is explicitly included in many of the regulatory measures addressing long-chain PFAS. The EU’s restriction on C9-C14 PFCAs (effective 2023) squarely covers PFTeDA (C14):contentReference[oaicite:509]{index=509}, banning its manufacture, use, or sale above a tiny threshold (25 ppb) in any product. Furthermore, PFTeDA and its salts have been listed as substances of very high concern (SVHC) under REACH, indicating recognition of its problematic nature. Internationally, PFTeDA falls under the 'related compounds' in the Stockholm Convention’s listing of PFOA (since they mentioned perfluorocarboxylic acids with ≥8 carbons, which would include C14), meaning parties must eliminate its uses and reduce releases. In the US, PFTeDA doesn’t have an individual guideline but it is captured under state regulatory frameworks as part of total PFAS or total PFCAs monitoring. For instance, Michigan’s groundwater standard includes up to C12, not C14 specifically, but cleanup efforts measure PFTeDA nonetheless to ensure full characterization. Analytical methods (EPA 537.1, 533) can measure PFTeDA in water, and labs do report it in comprehensive PFAS scans of drinking water (it’s often non-detect, but method capability is there ~ down to tens of ppt). Some states incorporate PFTeDA in their required PFAS monitoring for facilities – for example, Vermont and New York have asked certain sites to monitor for all chain lengths including PFTeDA. The forthcoming broad PFAS regulations (like the proposed EU PFAS ban, and potential class-based approaches in the US) implicitly include PFTeDA: if enacted, these will prohibit any future production or use of PFTeDA and mandate treatment technologies in waste streams to capture it. As of now, because PFTeDA is seldom found in water except near contamination hotspots, few places have needed specific remediation for it beyond what they do for PFOA/PFOS. But any comprehensive PFAS waste destruction technology (like high-temp incineration or advanced oxidation) must also target PFTeDA, which is challenging due to its stability. In summary, PFTeDA is regulated as part of the long-chain PFAS group internationally, is monitored in the environment as part of PFAS summation, and any identified contamination of PFTeDA is subject to the same cleanup requirements applied to PFOA/PFNA, reflecting a precautionary approach to this very persistent chemical.

Perfluorotridecanoic acid (PFTrDA) is a perfluorinated carboxylic acid with a 13-carbon chain (C12F25COOH). It's one of the high-molecular-weight PFCAs. Similar to PFTeDA (C14) and other long-chain PFAS, PFTrDA was not manufactured for specific end uses, but appeared as part of technical mixtures or as a minor byproduct. During the electrochemical fluorination process (used by 3M historically), a distribution of PFCAs up to C14 was produced, which would have included small amounts of C13 (PFTrDA). There were no known direct applications for PFTrDA in consumer or industrial products due to its extremely low volatility and high stability. However, trace levels might have been present in older AFFF firefighting foams or anti-reflective coatings used in photolithography, as those sometimes contained broad chain-length PFAS content. As industry moved to shorter PFAS, any incidental production of PFTrDA ceased. Essentially, PFTrDA’s “use” context aligns with other ultra-long PFAS: it's mainly relevant as a component detected in the environment and in some biota as a result of legacy PFAS pollution rather than as an intentionally used chemical. In summary, PFTrDA itself had no widespread use; its significance is tied to being one of the long-chain PFAS that historically ended up in the environment as part of PFAS manufacturing waste or product impurities.
Given PFTrDA’s properties (very low water solubility, strong sorption to organic matter), human exposure is likely to occur through the food chain and less so via water or air:
bullets: Dietary: PFTrDA bioaccumulates in aquatic and marine organisms. People consuming fish or marine mammals from PFAS-contaminated areas could ingest PFTrDA that has concentrated in those animals. Top-of-food-chain species (like certain predatory fish or seal meat in Arctic regions) have been found to contain PFTrDA, so subsistence fishers or communities relying on such food may get exposure through diet. Similarly, game meat or eggs from contaminated areas might contain trace PFTrDA, contributing to intake over time.

Drinking Water: PFTrDA is seldom detected in drinking water because it tends to stick to soils and sediment near sources. It’s relatively immobile in aquifers. If present, it’s usually at extremely low levels (below detection or single-digit ppt) even in impacted water. Thus, while theoretically ingestion through water is possible near a pollution source, practically it's a minor pathway compared to others. Standard water treatments (e.g., activated carbon) are highly effective at removing PFTrDA due to its hydrophobicity.

Inhalation: PFTrDA is non-volatile and would not be present in air except attached to particulates or aerosols. In communities near PFAS incineration or production (when it was happening), inhalation of dust containing PFTrDA could have occurred, but this is an uncommon scenario. Indoor air/dust in homes would not contain meaningful PFTrDA levels because it doesn't evaporate from products and most consumer items never had it in measurable quantity.

Occupational: Workers at sites where PFAS wastes (including long-chain PFCAs) are handled might be exposed via dust or dermal contact. For example, personnel cleaning up old firefighting foam residue or remediating soils could contact PFTrDA bound in those media. In historical context, lab chemists or production workers dealing with ECF byproducts might have been exposed if they handled unrefined mixtures containing PFTrDA. Appropriate protective equipment and environmental controls generally limit such exposures nowadays.

summary_sections.content: PFTrDA is close in chain length to PFTeDA (C14), so it's expected to behave similarly in biological systems. It is extremely persistent in the body – likely even more so than PFOA/PFNA – binding strongly to blood proteins and partitioning to the liver. No specific toxicology studies on PFTrDA have been released, but by analogy with other long PFCAs (C12-C14), it likely exerts potent peroxisome proliferation in rodent livers, causing significant liver enlargement, biochemical changes (e.g., induction of liver enzymes, reduction in serum lipids), and possibly liver damage at relatively low doses. It might also have greater immunosuppressive effects; PFCAs of C12 were found to reduce spleen and thymus weights in animal studies at moderate doses, which indicates immune system impact. Regarding developmental or reproductive toxicity, one might extrapolate that PFTrDA would cause lowered fetal weights or skeletal variations similar to PFOA but at lower concentrations due to its bioaccumulation – however, direct data are unavailable. Chronic exposure to PFTrDA could plausibly raise cancer risks in animals through mechanisms akin to PPAR-alpha activation leading to liver tumors (as seen with PFOA in rats), though again, no direct studies confirm this for PFTrDA specifically. Human data on PFTrDA is essentially absent. PFTrDA is rarely detectable in general population serum; it has been measured in highly exposed subgroups (like some fluorochemical plant workers) at very low parts-per-billion levels. Health outcomes specifically from PFTrDA haven't been assessed, but it's likely encompassed within observations of “total PFAS” effects. Given PFTrDA’s strong persistence and structural similarity to known toxic PFAS, regulatory bodies treat it as very hazardous by default. In summary, while PFTrDA itself hasn’t been deeply studied, all indications point to it being one of the more biologically active PFAS (owing to long persistence and bioaccumulative nature), thus raising concerns for liver toxicity, developmental effects, immune suppression, and possibly carcinogenic potential if exposure were significant over time.

PFTrDA is squarely within the scope of recent regulatory actions targeting long-chain PFAS. The EU REACH regulation that restricts C9-C14 PFCAs (effective July 2023) explicitly includes perfluorotridecanoic acid and its salts:contentReference[oaicite:512]{index=512}. This means manufacturing or using PFTrDA above trace levels in products is illegal in the EU, with only limited transitional exemptions (e.g., for some photolithography processes in electronics, which are time-limited). At the global level, since PFTrDA qualifies as a “C11+” perfluorocarboxylate, it is part of the group of PFAS encompassed by the PFOA listing under the Stockholm Convention (the treaty text for PFOA included its salts and PFCAs with 8+ carbons as related chemicals). Thus, parties are obligated to eliminate PFTrDA sources as well. In the US, PFTrDA is not individually regulated by EPA yet, but it’s on the radar: for example, when EPA issued Significant New Use Rules (SNURs) for certain PFAS, any long-chain PFCA including PFTrDA falls under requiring notification if any new manufacture or import is intended. Monitoring: Environmental agencies often check for PFTrDA in comprehensive site investigations; for instance, at PFAS-contaminated areas in Alabama or Minnesota, advanced analyses have reported PFTrDA in sediment or biota. Many commercial labs have the capability to measure PFTrDA in water down to tens of ppt, but it's usually reported qualitatively if detected, given lack of specific standards. Some states that regulate “total PFAS” in drinking water (like an upcoming Massachusetts approach) inherently include PFTrDA in the total. Remediation practices – such as soil thermal treatment or high-temperature incineration – must account for PFTrDA as it is one of the hardest to break PFAS; incomplete destruction could lead to it being a residual. On the horizon, any move by EPA to set a maximum contaminant level (MCL) for a sum of PFCAs might incorporate PFTrDA or at least consider it in risk calculations. Meanwhile, the trend is to treat it as part of the general PFAS class in bans; for example, the proposed EU PFAS ban would undeniably cover PFTrDA, disallowing any future use. In summary, regulatory focus on PFTrDA is through inclusion in group bans and restrictions of long-chain PFCAs; it is measured to ensure that 'total PFAS' objectives are met in cleanups and emissions, but it is not singled out with its own guideline value separate from those frameworks.

Perfluoroundecanoic acid (PFUnA) is an eleven-carbon perfluorinated carboxylic acid (C10F21COOH). It belongs to the group of long-chain PFCAs like PFNA (C9) and PFDoA (C12). PFUnA was not manufactured for any specific commercial product on its own. Instead, it has been present as a byproduct or impurity in processes making other PFAS (like PFOA or PFOS) and in some older products. For example, electrochemical fluorination (ECF) processes historically produced a mixture of PFCAs, including PFUnA, which found its way in small amounts into products such as AFFF firefighting foams and possibly surfactant blends used in industrial applications:contentReference[oaicite:515]{index=515}. In limited cases, PFUnA's ammonium salt may have been used in fluoropolymer emulsion polymerization as a replacement surfactant when PFOA was being phased out, though the industry primarily moved to shorter C6. There is some indication that certain Chinese fluorochemical manufacturers used mixtures containing PFUnA in the 2010s. That said, no known consumer-facing item has PFUnA intentionally; any PFUnA found would be as a residual. In summary, PFUnA had no discrete "uses"; its significance stems from being one component of PFAS contamination profiles and historically present in PFAS production wastes or in minor fractions of PFAS formulations:contentReference[oaicite:516]{index=516}.
Key exposure pathways for PFUnA mirror those of other long-chain PFAS, with emphasis on diet and water near contaminated sources:
bullets: Dietary Ingestion: PFUnA accumulates in fish, wildlife, and to some extent in plants. Humans can ingest PFUnA by eating fish from PFAS-polluted waters or consuming game animals (like deer or wildfowl) from contaminated areas. Studies in Arctic biota and Great Lakes fish have detected PFUnA, indicating that subsistence consumers of such resources may incorporate PFUnA into their diet. Additionally, trace PFUnA has been found in milk and eggs in surveys near contamination sites, suggesting a minor transfer into farm food products.

Drinking Water: PFUnA has been found in certain contaminated drinking water supplies, though usually at lower levels than PFOS/PFOA. It tends to sorb to carbon filters readily, so municipal treatment can remove it effectively. However, well water near PFAS facilities without treatment could contain PFUnA. For example, areas in West Virginia around a fluoropolymer plant found PFUnA in local wells. Ingesting untreated water from such sources is a pathway for affected residents.

House Dust and Indoor Environment: Because PFUnA was not used in consumer products deliberately, indoor exposure is minimal. It might be present in dust in homes near contamination sources (via outdoor deposition) or in the workplaces where contaminated clothing or equipment brings PFUnA-laden dust inside. But generally, indoor dust PFUnA levels are very low relative to shorter PFAS (if at all detectable).

Occupational: Workers at PFAS manufacturing sites in the past (e.g., 3M or DuPont) likely had PFUnA exposure along with other PFAS by inhalation of fumes and dust or skin contact. Firefighters or military personnel using legacy AFFFs might have had incidental PFUnA exposure since it was part of some foam formulations. Environmental remediation workers at PFAS sites also could be exposed to PFUnA through soil/dust contact or ingestion if hygiene is poor. These occupational exposures often manifested in higher blood PFUnA among such workers.

summary_sections.content: PFUnA’s toxicological behavior is expected to align with that of PFNA and PFDA. It is highly persistent in the body, with an estimated human half-life on the order of several years. Animal studies specifically on PFUnA are sparse; however, sub-chronic rodent studies on long-chain PFCAs have shown liver enlargement, alterations in thyroid hormone levels, and developmental toxicity at relatively low doses. PFUnA in particular was found in one study to lower body weight gain and cause neonatal mortality in mice at high doses (comparable to PFOA's effects). It strongly activates PPARα (a liver nuclear receptor), leading to increased fatty acid metabolism and potential liver cell proliferation. The EPA and ATSDR consider PFUnA’s toxicity comparable to PFOA/PFNA; indeed ATSDR’s minimal risk levels incorporate PFUnA as part of the total PFAS mixture affecting serum lipids and liver enzymes. Epidemiologically, PFUnA has been measured in human serum (e.g., NHANES and highly exposed community blood surveys). Some analyses found associations between higher PFUnA levels and elevated cholesterol, similar to other long-chain PFAS. There’s also evidence suggesting immunological effects (one study in a highly exposed group linked PFUnA to reduced vaccine antibody titers, though multiple PFAS were present). Carcinogenic potential specifically for PFUnA hasn't been separately evaluated, but given mechanistic parallels to PFOA (which is deemed likely carcinogenic), PFUnA is also treated as a potential cancer risk factor. On balance, PFUnA is considered to contribute to the known health risks of long-chain PFAS: including cholesterol changes, liver injury (enzyme elevation), immune system suppression, and developmental impacts (like lower birth weight):contentReference[oaicite:519]{index=519}. Regulatory health values (like EPA's advisory) for PFUnA are folded into those for PFOA/PFNA. In short, PFUnA is a highly persistent PFAS with significant toxic potential, and its presence in blood is considered as problematic as PFOA/PFNA from a health standpoint.

PFUnA is encompassed by the broad regulatory actions on long-chain PFAS. In the EU, PFUnA and its salts are restricted under the C9-C14 PFCA ban that took effect in 2023:contentReference[oaicite:521]{index=521}. This prohibits production or use in the EU beyond minuscule impurity levels. On the international stage, PFUnA is captured as a "related compound" under the Stockholm Convention listing for PFOA, which covers PFCAs with carbon chains of 9 or more (PFUnA being C11 is included). Accordingly, countries party to the Convention must eliminate sources of PFUnA. In the United States, PFUnA is monitored but not yet individually regulated by EPA; however, several state-level standards implicitly include PFUnA. For example, New York’s drinking water MCL of 10 ppt for “PFOS+PFHxS” indirectly forces water providers to control all PFAS including PFUnA via treatment processes. Michigan’s 6 PFAS MCL set (with 8 ppt PFOA, etc.) also measured PFUnA in establishing risk evaluation, although PFUnA itself wasn’t given an MCL because it was rarely found above detection in state water surveys. The EPA’s ongoing efforts (like the PFAS Roadmap) indicate possible future regulation via a hazard index which could include PFUnA’s toxicity contribution. Monitoring: PFUnA is part of the UCMR5 monitoring list for public water systems 2023-2025, meaning nationwide data will be collected. Many contaminated sites (e.g., around military bases using AFFF) now test for PFUnA in ground and surface waters; it often appears in the PFAS fingerprint. In biomonitoring, PFUnA has been measured in the general US population (NHANES 2013-2014 median around 0.2 ng/mL) and is included in the CDC’s PFAS biomonitoring panels. As regulatory focus moves toward addressing all long-chain PFAS collectively, PFUnA’s inclusion is assured. For instance, when EPA proposed class-based CERCLA designations or RCRA hazardous listing for PFAS, PFUnA would be one of those targeted. In remediation contexts, technologies like granular activated carbon and ion exchange are effective in removing PFUnA due to its hydrophobicity, which factor into cleanup plans where PFUnA is present. Overall, regulatory context treats PFUnA on par with PFOA/PFNA – to be eliminated and controlled, with ongoing monitoring to verify that emissions and exposures are diminishing over time.

Perfluoro-1-octanesulfonamide (FOSA) is a perfluorooctanesulfonyl-based compound that was a key intermediate and impurity in the production of certain PFOS-related chemicals. It has the formula C8F17SO2NH2. FOSA itself was not typically a final product, but it was used to make perfluorooctane sulfonamidoethanols which in turn were used in products like Scotchgard™ fabric protectors and other surface treatments:contentReference[oaicite:525]{index=525}:contentReference[oaicite:526]{index=526}. Additionally, FOSA was the active ingredient in certain insecticides; for example, "sulfluramid" (used in ant and roach baits) is an N-ethyl derivative of FOSA that breaks down to FOSA in the environment. During the era of PFOS production by 3M (before 2002), FOSA was present as a residual in some PFOS-based products (like firefighting foams and coating additives). It was also part of the PFOS manufacturing process (electrochemical fluorination yields perfluorooctane sulfonyl amides that could be converted to PFOS or derivatives). In summary, FOSA was primarily used as a chemical building block for PFOS-related compounds (like surfactants and insecticides) rather than a stand-alone commercial product sold to consumers. After PFOS was phased out, the production and use of FOSA largely ceased, aside from its continued minor presence via degradation of legacy materials (e.g., of sulfluramid):contentReference[oaicite:527]{index=527}.
Main exposure routes for FOSA include:
bullets: Dietary: FOSA can be found in food due to its use in insect baits and its persistence in the environment. One specific route is through the food chain: for example, FOSA has been detected in fish and marine mammals, especially in regions where PFOS-related compounds accumulate (FOSA is converted from sulfluramid used in agriculture/pest control, and travels into water). So eating contaminated fish or wild game could result in FOSA intake. Dairy and meats may contain trace FOSA if animals consumed FOSA-laden feed or water.

Indoor Dust: Historically, FOSA-related chemicals were in stain-resistant sprays and coatings on carpets/upholstery. These can degrade to FOSA. In indoor environments, FOSA has been measured in dust and air (attached to particulates). Thus, incidental ingestion of dust by hand-to-mouth contact, especially in homes that heavily used Scotchgard or similar pre-2003 products, could expose residents to small amounts of FOSA.

Drinking Water: FOSA itself is not very water-soluble (compared to PFOS), but it can still leach into groundwater near contaminated sites (e.g., manufacturing plants or firefighting training areas). Once in water, it may also degrade to PFOS. Nonetheless, FOSA has been detected in some water samples. Ingesting contaminated drinking water could be a pathway, though water treatment processes often remove much of these compounds.

Occupational: Workers formulating or applying PFOS-based treatments in the past (textile mill workers, foam manufacturers, pest control applicators using sulfluramid) likely inhaled or contacted FOSA-containing aerosols. Current occupational exposure might involve personnel involved in hazardous waste cleanup of PFOS-contaminated sites or disposal of sulfluramid pesticides, where they could inhale dust or fumes containing FOSA or have dermal contact.

Biotransformation from Precursors: An indirect 'pathway' is the body’s conversion of other compounds to FOSA. For example, if one ingests N-ethyl perfluorooctanesulfonamidoacetate (EtFOSAA, a PFOS precursor in the body), it can metabolize to FOSA. In this way, human exposure to precursors (through any of the above routes) can result in internal FOSA.

summary_sections.content: FOSA is closely related to PFOS (chemically, FOSA is one step removed, lacking the terminal acid group). Toxicologically, FOSA can be considered to have similar persistence and bioaccumulative behavior as PFOS. It is indeed found in human and animal tissues often along with PFOS. The body can also convert some FOSA to PFOS. Health studies haven't isolated FOSA's effects from PFOS because they co-occur. However, what is known: in lab animals, perfluorooctane sulfonamides (like FOSA derivatives) cause liver enlargement, disturbances in cholesterol and lipid metabolism, and developmental toxicity, much like PFOS:contentReference[oaicite:531]{index=531}. For example, sulfluramid (which metabolizes to FOSA) in high-dose rodent studies caused reduced body weight and some liver histopathology. FOSA and its derivatives have also been associated with immune suppression (in animal tests, they reduced antibody responses analogous to PFOS effect). There is limited direct data on FOSA carcinogenicity, but given PFOS's links to certain tumors in animal studies, similar concern extends to FOSA. Humans: FOSA is routinely measured in blood of the general population at low levels (e.g., NHANES through mid-2000s found low parts-per-billion of FOSA). Some epidemiological studies have noted associations between total sulfonamide PFAS (often measured as FOSA or its precursors) and thyroid hormone disruptions or slight changes in reproductive hormones, though causality isn't established. Notably, because FOSA can convert to PFOS in vivo, part of its toxicity may manifest through PFOS's well-documented mechanisms (like PPARα activation, etc.). Overall, FOSA is regarded as a toxic PFAS: persistent, bioaccumulative, and capable of similar systemic effects as PFOS (liver toxicity, developmental harm, potential endocrine disruption):contentReference[oaicite:532]{index=532}.
