Regulatory assessments often treat FOSA as part of PFOS risk (for example, Health Canada includes FOSA in their PFOS blood guideline calculations since it adds to PFOS burden). In summary, detection of FOSA in blood indicates exposure to PFOS-related compounds and is associated with the same health concerns as PFOS exposure.

Regulators worldwide have targeted FOSA as part of the measures against PFOS and its precursors. When PFOS was listed under the Stockholm Convention in 2009, that listing explicitly covered "perfluorooctane sulfonamide" and other precursors that can degrade to PFOS. Therefore, FOSA is internationally regulated for elimination except in certain exempt uses (the primary exemptions have been for sulfluramid insect baits in a few countries and aviation hydraulic fluids, but those are being phased out). In the EU, FOSA and its derivatives have been banned since 2008 along with PFOS (Directive 2006/122/EC). The manufacture and import of FOSA-related chemicals in the US effectively ended with 3M's voluntary phase-out by 2002. The US EPA includes FOSA (and EtFOSA, etc.) in its Significant New Use Rule (SNUR) prohibiting new uses of these PFOS-precursors. Monitoring: Environmental monitoring programs measure FOSA in wildlife and humans as part of PFOS precursor analysis. For instance, the Arctic Monitoring and Assessment Programme tracks FOSA in polar bears and birds because it can indicate ongoing sources of PFOS-precursors like sulfluramid:contentReference[oaicite:534]{index=534}. Drinking water regulations haven't singled out FOSA but treat it under PFOS grouping; e.g., EPA's health advisory for PFOS (0.02 ppt interim in 2022) inherently covers exposure to FOSA that converts to PFOS. Some states with PFOS MCLs implicitly require monitoring of FOSA in water to ensure total PFOS + precursors is addressed, since activated carbon might not remove FOSA as easily but if left, it could transform to PFOS post-treatment. Cleanups of contaminated sites consider FOSA as part of the total PFOS contamination; for example, at military sites, they've tested for FOSA in groundwater to fully characterize PFAS plumes. Regulatory frameworks now increasingly emphasize total "PFOS and precursors" – e.g., the EU POPs regulation has threshold limits not just for PFOS itself but also for compounds that can form PFOS (which includes FOSA). Essentially, FOSA is regulated almost everywhere PFOS is, recognizing its role as a PFOS progenitor. There remain allowances for the pesticide sulfluramid (which breaks down to FOSA and PFOS) in certain countries, but alternatives are being encouraged and those exemptions are periodically reviewed under Stockholm Convention. In summary, FOSA is under strict global control as part of PFOS-related substances, and ongoing monitoring in environment and food ensures that any residual sources of FOSA are identified and mitigated along with PFOS.

9-Chlorohexadecafluoro-3-oxanonane-1-sulfonic acid, also known by the shorthand 9Cl-PF3ONS, is a fluorinated sulfonic acid that is a key component of certain Chinese PFAS formulations often referred to as F-53B. This chemical is a chlorinated perfluoroether sulfonate (with an 8:2 fluorotelomer structure plus a chlorine). It was introduced as a replacement mist suppressant in the chrome plating industry in China, intended to serve a similar function to PFOS-based surfactants:contentReference[oaicite:540]{index=540}. F-53B formulations typically contain two major acids: this 9-chlorohexadecafluoro-3-oxanonane-1-sulfonic acid and a related sulfonic acid without the chloro group (both collectively called F-53B). They have been used since around 2014 in Chinese chrome plating to reduce toxic chromic acid mists:contentReference[oaicite:541]{index=541}. Outside of that context, this chemical has no known consumer use; its application is specialized and industrial. It is not produced or widely used in Western countries, but it has been detected as a pollutant originating from Chinese manufacturing and usage. In summary, the common use of 9Cl-PF3ONS is as a surfactant in metal plating (in China), and it gained attention as an emerging PFAS pollutant globally due to its environmental release from those uses:contentReference[oaicite:542]{index=542}.
Exposure to 9Cl-PF3ONS for the general population is currently rare and localized, but known pathways include:
bullets: Drinking Water: Near facilities in China where 9Cl-PF3ONS (F-53B) is manufactured or used (e.g., industrial parks, chrome plating shops), this compound has been found in nearby water bodies. If drinking water sources are contaminated (as was reported in some regions of China), ingestion could be a major pathway:contentReference[oaicite:545]{index=545}. Outside of China, given global circulation, traces of 9Cl-PF3ONS have been detected in surface waters and even Arctic seawater, though at extremely low levels. Thus, currently, drinking water exposure in most parts of the world is negligible, but it could become relevant in areas importing industrial materials or wastes from those sources.

Food Chain: This PFAS can bioaccumulate. Monitoring has found 9Cl-PF3ONS in fish downstream of Chinese plating facilities. Humans eating contaminated fish or seafood could intake it. Additionally, because of long-range transport, there is concern it could appear in marine food webs globally. However, data is limited; any food exposure is likely region-specific (e.g., seafood from affected Chinese rivers).

Occupational: Workers at chrome plating facilities using F-53B mist suppressants have direct exposure via inhalation of plating bath aerosols or skin contact with the concentrate. These workers may inhale small droplets containing the acid or touch surfaces where it has deposited. Occupational exposure is also possible for those handling industrial wastewater or sludge from such operations (the chemical could concentrate in waste). Appropriate engineering controls and personal protective equipment (PPE) are critical in these settings to minimize inhalation or dermal uptake.

Urban and Indoor: Considering its specialized use, urban air or dust far from source is unlikely to contain significant 9Cl-PF3ONS. There's no consumer product usage, so indoor exposure in homes is essentially zero. However, near plating shops, it's possible this chemical could deposit on soil/dust around the facility and potentially be incidentally ingested by residents or bystanders (e.g., kids playing near an improperly ventilated shop could contact soil with deposition). This is a minor but plausible local pathway.

summary_sections.content: As an emerging PFAS, specific toxicological data on 9Cl-PF3ONS are not abundant, but early studies and structural analogy to PFOS suggest cause for concern. It is an even larger molecule than PFOS and contains an ether linkage plus a chlorine, which may influence its behavior. Lab studies (one rat subacute study reported by Chinese researchers) indicated that 9Cl-PF3ONS exposure led to liver weight increases and changes in serum biochemical indices, similar to PFOS:contentReference[oaicite:547]{index=547}. It appears to activate PPARα and potentially other pathways akin to PFOS, resulting in disrupted lipid metabolism. Its elimination half-life in rats was reported to be long (on the order of weeks), and in humans it's expected to be very persistent (maybe even longer than PFOS's ~5 years given its larger size). Preliminary ecotoxicology shows it's very toxic to aquatic organisms (with low parts-per-billion LC50s for fish). So far, no epidemiological data exist since its use has been recent and limited to certain worker populations. However, we can expect health effects analogous to PFOS/PFHxS: e.g., liver enzyme elevation, potential developmental toxicity (if pregnant workers were exposed, PFAS of this nature often reduce fetal growth in animal tests), and possibly immune effects. The chlorine substitution might make it less bioaccumulative in some tissues (there's some evidence that 9Cl-PF3ONS might partition differently in fish), but it's still detected in blood and liver. Overall, given its strong structural similarity to PFOS, health agencies (like China's guidelines) treat it as similarly hazardous. Thus, exposure to 9Cl-PF3ONS is thought to carry risks of liver damage, endocrine disruption (such as thyroid hormone perturbation, seen with PFOS analogs), and developmental harm. It's also possible that like PFOS, it's a potential carcinogen (though no specific study on 9Cl-PF3ONS exists, PFOS is considered possibly carcinogenic by some agencies). The cautious approach is to assume 9Cl-PF3ONS shares the adverse profile of long-chain sulfonates and thus avoid human exposure as much as possible.

9Cl-PF3ONS (often referred to as 6:2 chlorinated polyfluorinated ether sulfonate or simply F-53B major component) has come onto regulators’ radar as part of China's PFAS emissions and globally as an "emerging" PFAS. In China, its use in chrome plating was approved as an alternative to PFOS, but recently Chinese authorities have moved to control it due to detection in the environment. It's included in China's national environmental monitoring list for toxic substances and pilot studies to replace it with even safer alternatives are underway. Internationally, this chemical and its counterpart are proposed for inclusion under the Stockholm Convention: In 2019, the POPs Review Committee agreed that these F-53B substances exhibit POPs characteristics:contentReference[oaicite:549]{index=549}, and as of 2022 they are under evaluation for global restriction. Some countries have already taken unilateral steps: e.g., Sweden and Germany have pushed within EU fora to address it, and the EU’s sweeping PFAS restriction proposal would cover it as well. Currently, there's no specific EU or US regulatory limit solely for 9Cl-PF3ONS in drinking water or products, but any general PFAS limits (e.g., the EU's upcoming 4 ng/L sum of PFAS in water) will indirectly require its control. Monitoring is increasing: countries like Japan and Sweden have begun checking imported chrome plating products for F-53B, and scientists globally are measuring it in environmental samples (the Arctic monitoring found it in polar bears, prompting concern). The US does not yet have formal guidelines, but the EPA is aware; if they move to regulate PFAS as a class, this chemical would be encompassed. Given the interest by Stockholm Convention, it's likely to be globally regulated within a few years. Meanwhile, industries using it (in China primarily) are being nudged to shift to fluorine-free mist suppressants, anticipating regulation. In summary, 9Cl-PF3ONS is in a transitional state of regulation: known enough to be targeted for global action and included in broad PFAS policies, but not yet individually restricted worldwide. Monitoring and research are actively feeding into that regulatory process, with an expectation of eventual phase-out just like PFOS.

1H,1H,2H,2H-Perfluorodecanesulfonic acid, often referred to as 8:2 fluorotelomer sulfonic acid (8:2 FTS), is a partially fluorinated sulfonate. Unlike fully perfluorinated PFOS, this molecule has two hydrogen atoms on the first two carbons, making it a "telomer" sulfonate. 8:2 FTS emerged as a replacement for PFOS in certain applications, notably in firefighting foams (AFFF) and other surfactant uses, after PFOS was phased out:contentReference[oaicite:555]{index=555}. It has been used in some modern AFFF formulations to impart film-forming and wetting properties while being shorter-lived than PFOS. Additionally, 8:2 FTS is a processing aid in some specialty chemical formulations and may be found in trace amounts in surface treatment products (like coatings for textiles or paper) that utilize fluorotelomer chemistry. As industries shifted to "C6" chemistry for many products, 8:2 FTS usage is somewhat limited now, but it was a key component in foams through the 2010s. To sum up, the primary use of 1H,1H,2H,2H-perfluorodecanesulfonic acid has been as an ingredient in certain firefighting foam concentrates and similar surfactant mixtures as a PFOS alternative:contentReference[oaicite:556]{index=556}. It is not known to be sold directly to consumers, but rather embedded in these specialty industrial products.
Exposure to 8:2 FTS for the general public primarily occurs via contaminated environments, since it's used in firefighting and can enter the environment through training or emergency use of foams:
bullets: Drinking Water: Sites where AFFF containing 8:2 FTS has been used (like military bases, airports, firefighter training areas) have shown contamination of groundwater. As 8:2 FTS is water-soluble (though less so than shorter chains) and mobile, it can reach wells or surface water, leading to ingestion via drinking water:contentReference[oaicite:558]{index=558}. Indeed, 8:2 FTS has been found in some municipal water supplies near such sites. Thus, drinking water in affected areas is a significant pathway if not treated.

Food: There is potential for 8:2 FTS to bioaccumulate moderately. For instance, fish from water bodies impacted by firefighting foam releases might have 8:2 FTS in their tissue. People eating fish from these areas could ingest it. Similarly, agricultural produce or livestock near contaminated water sources might take up some 8:2 FTS (though plants and animals tend to metabolize telomer sulfonates partially to shorter compounds). In general, diet is a secondary pathway compared to water, but relevant for subsistence fishermen or farms using contaminated water.

Indoor Dust and Consumer Products: While 8:2 FTS isn't a consumer product, it can be present in treated materials (like some older carpet or fabric coatings). If those coatings degrade, 8:2 FTS could be present in household dust. Inhalation or ingestion of dust (especially by infants/toddlers) could provide a minor exposure route. However, many post-2010 consumer products moved to shorter chain PFAS, so current levels of 8:2 FTS in homes may be low. Firefighters or foam handlers might carry foam residue into their stations or homes on gear, which could be a more direct dust source in those specific scenarios.

Occupational: Firefighters who handle training foams or respond to fuel fires with foam can inhale aerosolized 8:2 FTS or have skin contact with foam solution. Instructors at fire academies (historically using older foams) could have chronic exposure. Workers at facilities producing 8:2 FTS or blending foams would also have potential inhalation or dermal exposure. Using personal protective equipment and proper hygiene (e.g., washing foam-soaked gear) is critical to reduce these exposures.

Environmental Contact: Residents near contaminated sites might incidentally ingest soil or water (while swimming or playing) that contains 8:2 FTS. Also, because AFFF runoff often gets into lakes and rivers, recreation in these water bodies (swimming, boating) could lead to incidental ingestion or dermal absorption of small amounts, though the risk is generally low except near heavy contamination sources.

summary_sections.content: 8:2 FTS is partially fluorinated, and studies suggest it is less bioaccumulative than PFOS but can still persist in humans for some time (half-life on the order of months). Toxicologically, 8:2 FTS can undergo metabolism to shorter-chain PFAS (like perfluorooctanoic acid and PFHxS), which complicates attributing effects solely to it. Animal experiments with 8:2 FTS have shown some of the hallmark PFAS effects: liver enlargement, increased liver enzymes, and changes in lipid profiles at high doses, though potency was observed to be lower than PFOS:contentReference[oaicite:560]{index=560}. A 90-day rodent study indicated that 8:2 FTS caused mild liver cellular changes and body weight decreases at the highest concentrations. Reproductive/developmental data are sparse, but one would expect similar endpoints (e.g., lowered pup weight or slight developmental delays at maternally toxic doses, as seen with similar PFAS). Immunotoxicity hasn't been well characterized; however, since 8:2 FTS breaks down into PFHxS (which is known to affect the immune system), there's concern that 8:2 FTS exposure could indirectly contribute to immune suppression. There is no direct evidence that 8:2 FTS causes cancer, but long-term studies are lacking. It's noteworthy that many 8:2 FTS health effects might come from its metabolites more than the parent compound. Human data on 8:2 FTS specifically is limited because it's often not measured in blood (it can convert to other PFAS or present at low levels). Regulators often consider 8:2 FTS under the umbrella of "PFOS replacement chemicals" for risk assessment. Overall, 8:2 FTS is considered of moderate concern: it is less bioaccumulative and slightly less toxic than PFOS, but still can produce similar adverse outcomes (particularly liver and metabolic effects) at sufficiently high exposures:contentReference[oaicite:561]{index=561}. As such, reducing exposure to it is part of broader PFAS risk management due to these potential health impacts.

8:2 FTS is not regulated with its own specific standards yet, but it falls under many collective PFAS regulatory efforts. In the United States, the EPA’s recent advisory levels for PFOS (and by extension PFAS foams) imply that 8:2 FTS, as a component of foams, should be minimized to extremely low concentrations in drinking water (the EPA health advisory for GenX and PFBS indirectly covers short-chain sulfonates; for 8:2 FTS they don't have a number, but states have taken action). For instance, some states (like Michigan) include 8:2 FTS in their environmental PFAS surveillance and require its analysis in water, though their drinking water criteria focus on other PFAS. On the federal side, 8:2 FTS is included in the UCMR5 (Unregulated Contaminant Monitoring Rule 2023-25) list for nationwide drinking water testing. In the EU, while not explicitly named in older directives, the upcoming PFAS drinking water limit of 100 ng/L for total PFAS will cover 8:2 FTS. Additionally, the EU is moving to ban all per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances in consumer products, which would include 8:2 FTS used in foams. Some European countries have already replaced or restricted foams containing 8:2 FTS under their chemical and environmental regulations. Monitoring: Many contaminated site investigations now measure 8:2 FTS in groundwater and surface water to understand the full suite of PFAS present from AFFFs. It's often reported in site cleanup documents and is treated in remediation systems (like GAC filters in water treatment are sized to also capture 8:2 FTS). The Stockholm Convention hasn't listed 8:2 FTS yet, but as they consider more PFAS beyond PFOS/PFOA, compounds like 8:2 FTS might be evaluated in the future. Firefighting foam stewardship programs in the US encourage the transition away from PFAS foams (which would eliminate 8:2 FTS use). In summary, while no numeric MCL exists solely for 8:2 FTS, it's increasingly captured by broad regulations (sum of PFAS limits in water, restrictions on PFAS in products). Environmental regulators and water utilities are actively monitoring it, and its presence factors into site remediation goals (e.g., cleanup levels for "total PFAS"). The clear trend is toward phasing out use of foams containing 8:2 FTS, reflecting precaution due to its persistence and potential toxicity.
An industrial monomer used to produce polycarbonate plastics and epoxy resins (e.g., can linings, coatings). Consumer exposure has been widespread due to legacy use in food-contact materials.
Diet is the main route (migration from food-contact materials); additional exposure via dust and thermal paper is possible.
bullets: Dietary ingestion from epoxy/polycarbonate contact
Incidental ingestion of dust and hand-to-mouth transfer
Occupational contact in resin manufacture/handling

summary_sections.content: Biomarkers include unconjugated and conjugated BPA in urine (short half-life; blood detection suggests recent exposure). Endpoints studied include endocrine activity and immune endpoints; EFSA (2023) based its TDI on immune effects in animals.
EFSA (2023) set a TDI of 0.2 ng/kg bw/day; many jurisdictions restrict BPA in infant products/thermal paper. BPA is routinely tracked in NHANES biomonitoring tables.
A fully perfluorinated C10 sulfonic acid found as a minor component of historical PFAS mixtures; not intentionally used in consumer products today.
Dietary intake from fish/wildlife and, to a lesser extent, impacted water near sources; occupational exposure at legacy facilities.
bullets: Fish consumption in contaminated waters
Ingestion of impacted drinking water near sources

summary_sections.content: Long-chain sulfonate with high persistence and bioaccumulation; PFAS-typical hepatic, immune, and developmental endpoints observed for related sulfonates.
Covered within long-chain PFAS policies and Stockholm Convention–related controls; measured in environmental/biota PFAS datasets.
A fully perfluorinated C9 sulfonic acid present as a minor constituent of historical PFAS streams; not a typical intentional consumer chemical.
Similar to other long-chain sulfonates: ingestion of impacted water and fish are principal routes; occupational contact at legacy sites.
bullets: Ingestion of contaminated water
Dietary intake via fish/wildlife from impacted waters

summary_sections.content: Persistent/bioaccumulative; expected PFAS-typical endpoints (liver, immune, developmental) by analogy to PFOS/PFDS. Blood detection indicates cumulative exposure.
Included in congener panels for environmental/biota monitoring; managed under broader PFAS controls and cleanup criteria.

A fluorotelomer sulfonic acid (FTS) belonging to the per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS). It is used as a surfactant and processing aid in water- and oil‑repellent coatings, industrial formulations, and has been reported in firefighting foam formulations; it may also form from degradation of fluorotelomer precursors.
Human exposure reflects contact with fluorinated surfactants and contaminated environmental media; measured levels in blood indicate recent or ongoing exposure.
bullets: Ingestion of contaminated drinking water near sites using aqueous film‑forming foams (AFFF) or industrial discharges.
Inhalation or ingestion of indoor dust from treated textiles and stain‑resistant materials.
Dietary intake (contact materials, bioaccumulation in some foods).
Occupational exposure in textile finishing, metal plating, or foam use.

summary_sections.content: PFAS are typically assessed in serum; detection in blood indicates systemic exposure. For 4:2 FTS specifically, human toxicokinetic data are limited; available studies and reviews evaluate binding to serum proteins and potential effects similar to other surfactants, with research focusing on liver, endocrine, and developmental endpoints without inferring causality.

4:2 FTS has no compound‑specific U.S. drinking water Maximum Contaminant Level (MCL). It appears on laboratory analyte lists and EPA methods used for environmental monitoring (e.g., SW‑846 Method 8327; Draft Method 1633).

A fluorotelomer sulfonic acid used as a surfactant and PFOS alternative in certain industrial and firefighting foam applications. It is a member of the PFAS class and may occur from degradation of fluorotelomer precursors.
Exposure is associated with contact with treated products and impacted environmental media.
bullets: Drinking water affected by AFFF use or industrial releases.
Indoor dust from stain‑resistant textiles and treated surfaces.
Dietary exposure via food contact materials or contaminated foods.
Occupational settings using or handling fluorotelomer products.

summary_sections.content: As with other PFAS, serum is the common biomonitoring matrix; detection in blood indicates systemic exposure. Available literature for 6:2 FTS evaluates protein binding and potential biological activity; endpoints studied include hepatic, endocrine, and development‑related measures.
No compound‑specific U.S. MCL. The analyte is included on PFAS monitoring lists used with EPA analytical methods (e.g., Method 8327 and Draft Method 1633) for environmental samples.

A perfluoroalkyl sulfonic acid (PFSA) with five‑carbon chain length used as a specialty surfactant and detected as an environmental PFAS. It can occur as an impurity or degradation product of other PFAS.
Exposure largely reflects environmental and product‑related contact typical of PFSAs.
bullets: Ingestion of contaminated drinking water.
Ingestion/inhalation of indoor dust from treated materials.
Dietary exposure from food or contact materials.
Occupational exposure in PFAS production or application.

summary_sections.content: Serum measurements indicate systemic exposure. For PFPeS, human toxicokinetic and effect data are comparatively limited; evaluations of PFSAs generally consider liver, lipid, thyroid, and immune endpoints in experimental and observational studies without assigning causality.
No compound‑specific U.S. MCL. PFPeS appears on PFAS analyte lists used by agencies and laboratories for environmental monitoring.
A four‑carbon perfluoroalkyl sulfonic acid (PFSA) used as a surfactant and historically as a PFOS replacement in stain‑repellent and industrial applications.
PFBS exposure occurs via environmental media and treated products; it is often detected where PFAS use has occurred.
bullets: Ingestion of contaminated drinking water.
Indoor dust from treated carpets/upholstery.
Dietary intake via contact materials or foods.
Occupational exposure in manufacturing or foam use.

summary_sections.content: In humans, short‑chain PFAS such as PFBS generally have shorter biological half‑lives than long‑chain PFAS; blood detection indicates recent exposure. Evaluated endpoints include hepatic, thyroid, lipid, and immunological measures.

In April 2024, the U.S. EPA finalized National Primary Drinking Water Regulations (NPDWR) for PFAS, using a Hazard Index for mixtures that include PFBS along with PFNA, PFHxS, and HFPO‑DA (GenX). PFBS is commonly included in PFAS analyte lists and measured in NHANES serum panels.
A seven‑carbon perfluoroalkyl sulfonic acid (PFSA). PFHpS has been detected in environmental and human samples as a PFOS‑related PFSA and as a surfactant in specialty applications.
Pathways are consistent with other PFSAs.
bullets: Ingestion of PFAS‑impacted drinking water.
Indoor dust from stain‑resistant products.
Dietary intake from contact materials or fish/meat where bioaccumulation occurs.
Occupational use of PFAS‑containing formulations.

summary_sections.content: Serum is the principal biomonitoring matrix for PFSAs; detection in blood indicates systemic exposure. Studies of PFAS class effects often evaluate liver function, lipids, thyroid hormones, and immune endpoints.
No compound‑specific U.S. MCL. PFHpS appears on EPA and state analyte lists and is included in research and monitoring of serum PFAS.
A six‑carbon perfluoroalkyl sulfonic acid (PFSA) historically used in AFFF and surface‑treatment formulations for stain, water, and oil resistance.
PFHxS is widely detected in serum and environmental media due to historical use and persistence.
bullets: Ingestion of contaminated drinking water (e.g., AFFF‑impacted sites).
Indoor dust from treated carpets/upholstery and consumer articles.
Dietary exposure including fish and meat in some studies.
Occupational exposure in firefighting, plating, and surface treatment.

summary_sections.content: Serum detection reflects systemic exposure; PFHxS has a comparatively long human elimination half‑life (multi‑year). Studies commonly examine liver enzymes/lipids, thyroid hormones, immunological markers, and developmental endpoints.

The U.S. EPA’s 2024 PFAS drinking water rule applies a Hazard Index for mixtures that include PFHxS. PFHxS and related compounds were listed under the Stockholm Convention in 2022 (Annex A). PFHxS is routinely included in NHANES serum monitoring.

A dialkyl phthalate plasticizer used historically in flexible polyvinyl chloride (PVC) and other polymers. Use patterns have shifted as some phthalates have been replaced or restricted in certain applications.
Phthalate exposure often reflects contact with consumer products and indoor environments; parent phthalates are rapidly metabolized.
bullets: Ingestion of dust containing plasticizer residues.
Dietary exposure via food contact materials.
Dermal contact with flexible plastics.
Occupational exposure during polymer processing.

summary_sections.content: Detection of the parent in blood would imply recent exposure; however, biomonitoring commonly relies on urinary metabolites (e.g., mono‑n‑hexyl phthalate, MnHexP) rather than parent compounds in serum. Research on phthalates frequently examines reproductive, developmental, hepatic, and endocrine‑related endpoints.

Phthalates are regulated under various frameworks (e.g., EU REACH restrictions and authorisation for several phthalates; compound‑specific provisions vary). Biomonitoring programs (e.g., NHANES and state programs) measure phthalate metabolites in urine to assess exposure trends.
A bisphenol used in epoxy resins, adhesives, industrial coatings, and as a BPA substitute in some applications.
Exposure occurs via contact with materials made using BPF‑based resins and from consumer products.
bullets: Dietary intake via can linings and contact materials.
Dermal contact with resins/coatings and occupational handling.
Indoor dust ingestion.
Urinary biomonitoring captures recent exposure.

summary_sections.content: Blood detection would indicate recent exposure; most biomonitoring relies on urine (conjugated metabolites). Literature evaluates endocrine‑related, developmental, and reproductive endpoints.

BPF is included in biomonitoring panels (e.g., U.S. NHANES urinary measurements in selected cycles). Regulatory assessments for bisphenols have mainly focused on BPA; BPF is being evaluated in several jurisdictions.
A perfluoroalkyl carboxylic acid (PFCA) with a 12‑carbon chain detected in environmental and biological samples; formed as a manufacturing by‑product or from degradation of precursor PFAS.
Long‑chain PFCAs are persistent and bioaccumulative; human exposure reflects environmental contamination and consumer products.
bullets: Ingestion of contaminated drinking water.
Dietary intake, particularly fish and some meats (bioaccumulation).
Indoor dust ingestion and contact with treated materials.
Occupational exposure in fluorochemical production or use.

summary_sections.content: Serum PFCA measurements indicate systemic exposure and body burden due to multi‑year half‑lives in humans for long‑chain PFAAs. Endpoints studied include liver function, lipids, thyroid hormones, and immune measures.

In the EU, C9–C14 PFCAs (which include PFDoA/C12) and related substances are restricted under REACH (Commission Regulation (EU) 2021/1297; effective dates in 2023). PFDoA appears in PFAS monitoring programs and analyte lists.
An eight‑carbon perfluoroalkyl carboxylic acid (PFCA) used historically as a processing aid in fluoropolymer manufacture; also detected as an environmental contaminant.
PFOA is persistent and widely measured in serum; exposure is associated with multiple environmental and product pathways.
bullets: Ingestion of contaminated drinking water near industrial/AFFF sites.
Dietary intake from food or contact materials.
Indoor dust ingestion and consumer product contact.
Occupational exposure in fluorochemical production or use.

summary_sections.content: Serum detection reflects body burden; human half‑life is on the order of years. Studies commonly assess hepatic, lipid, thyroid, immune, developmental, and renal biomarkers.

In April 2024, the U.S. EPA finalized an MCL of 4 ng/L (ppt) for PFOA in drinking water and designated PFOA a hazardous substance under CERCLA in 2024. PFOA was listed under the Stockholm Convention (2019).
A perfluoroalkyl sulfonic acid (PFSA) used historically in AFFF, metal plating mist suppressants, and stain‑/water‑repellent surface treatments; phased out or restricted in many jurisdictions.
PFOS is persistent and bioaccumulative; serum monitoring shows widespread exposure.
bullets: Ingestion of contaminated drinking water.
Dietary exposure (e.g., fish/meat) in some settings.
Indoor dust ingestion from treated materials.
Occupational exposure in plating, AFFF use, or historical manufacturing.

summary_sections.content: Serum detection reflects long half‑lives in humans (years). Evaluated endpoints include hepatic function, lipids, thyroid hormones, immune markers, and developmental measures.

The U.S. EPA set a drinking water MCL of 4 ng/L (ppt) for PFOS in 2024; PFOS was designated a CERCLA hazardous substance in 2024. Internationally, PFOS and its salts/precursor PFOSF were listed under the Stockholm Convention in 2009 (Annex B).
A perfluorooctane sulfonamide derivative (PFOS precursor) used historically in surface treatment chemistries; it can degrade to PFOS. NEtFOSAA is a PFAS measured as a precursor biomarker in serum.
Exposure reflects contact with PFOS‑based chemistries and their transformation products.
bullets: Ingestion of drinking water influenced by historical PFOS uses.
Indoor dust from treated materials (e.g., stain‑resistant finishes).
Dietary exposure via contact materials.
Occupational exposure to PFOS‑related products.

summary_sections.content: NEtFOSAA in serum indicates exposure to PFOS‑related precursors; studies examine placental transfer and its role in PFOS body burden. Endpoints studied include those commonly assessed for PFAS (hepatic, lipid, thyroid, immune).

NEtFOSAA is not assigned a stand‑alone U.S. drinking water MCL; it has been measured in NHANES special serum PFAS panels (e.g., children 2013–2014). PFOS (a degradation product) has enforceable drinking water standards in the U.S. (2024).
A perfluorooctane sulfonamide‑based PFAS (PFOS precursor) associated with historical surface treatment uses; monitored as a precursor biomarker in serum.
Exposure arises from historical PFOS‑related chemistries and environmental transformation.
bullets: Ingestion of impacted drinking water.
Indoor dust from treated textiles and surface treatments.
Dietary contact via packaging/linings.
Occupational contact with PFOS‑related products.

summary_sections.content: NMeFOSAA in serum indicates exposure to PFOS‑precursor compounds; studies report maternal–fetal transfer and evaluate contributions to PFOS body burden. Endpoints studied align with broader PFAS evaluations (hepatic, lipid, thyroid, immune).
No stand‑alone U.S. MCL. NMeFOSAA has been included in NHANES special serum PFAS panels and appears on PFAS analytical lists; PFOS, a degradation product, has a 2024 U.S. drinking water MCL.
